    Structure-Based Design and Evaluation of Naphthalene Diimide G-Quadruplex Ligands As Telomere Targeting Agents in Pancreatic Cancer Cells

    • Marialuisa Micco
      • , 
    • Gavin W. Collie
      • , 
    • Aaron G. Dale
      • , 
    • Stephan A. Ohnmacht
      • , 
    • Ingrida Pazitna

    Abstract

    Tetra-substituted naphthalene diimide (ND) derivatives with positively charged termini are potent stabilizers of human telomeric and gene promoter DNA quadruplexes and inhibit the growth of human cancer cells in vitro and in vivo. The present study reports the enhancement of the pharmacological properties of earlier ND compounds using structure-based design. Crystal structures of three complexes with human telomeric intramolecular quadruplexes demonstrate that two of the four strongly basic N-methyl-piperazine groups can be replaced by less basic morpholine groups with no loss of intermolecular interactions in the grooves of the quadruplex. The new compounds retain high affinity to human telomeric quadruplex DNA but are 10-fold more potent against the MIA PaCa-2 pancreatic cancer cell line, with IC50 values of ∼10 nM. The lead compound induces cellular senescence but does not inhibit telomerase activity at the nanomolar dosage levels required for inhibition of cellular proliferation. Gene array qPCR analysis of MIA PaCa-2 cells treated with the lead compound revealed significant dose-dependent modulation of a distinct subset of genes, including strong induction of DNA damage responsive genes CDKN1A, DDIT3, GADD45A/G, and PPM1D, and repression of genes involved in telomere maintenance, including hPOT1 and PARP1.

    Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The formation of G-quadruplexes, noncanonical guanine-rich four-stranded DNA secondary structures, has been extensively demonstrated by biophysical and structural methods(1) and has recently been definitively validated in human cells at both telomeric and nontelomeric chromosomal regions.(2) The concept that small molecules can sequester the single-stranded overhang of human telomeric DNA into higher-order quadruplex DNA structures(3) has been validated by a number of studies.(4) It has also been shown that the resulting stabilized quadruplex–ligand complexes can interfere with the processivity of the reverse transcriptase telomerase enzyme complex and so inhibit the ability of this enzyme to maintain telomere integrity in the majority of cancer cell types, where it is up-regulated.(3-5) The validity of this approach to selectively interfere with cancer cell viability has been demonstrated for several classes of quadruplex-binding molecules in cells and in tumor xenograft experiments,(5) resulting, for example, from induction of apoptosis and replicative senescence achieved through selective DNA damage or down-regulation of oncogenic promoter expression.(3, 6, 22)
    Quadruplex targeting has also been shown to provoke a DNA damage response in cells(6a) and in vivo,(6c) for example, in the case of the acridinium compound 3,11-difluoro-6,8,13-trimethyl-8H-quino[4,3,2-kl]acridiniummethosulfate (RHPS4),(6a, 6c) whereas telomerase inhibition is directly linked to the action of the trisubstituted acridine compound 3,6-bis(3-pyrrolidin-1-ylpropionamido)-9-(4-dimethylaminophenylamino)acridine (BRACO19).(7)
    A number of recent studies have utilized the naphthalene diimide (ND) core as a quadruplex-binding motif, on account of its combination of chemical accessibility and extended planar surfaces suggestive of favorable quadruplex-binding.(8) Most of these published studies have focused on mono-, di- or trisubstituted compounds. We have previously described a series of tetra-substituted ND compounds with high affinity for human telomeric quadruplex DNA.(9-11) These also have high potency for growth inhibition in a panel of cancer cell lines, concomitant with telomerase inhibition. Their ability to displace the human protection of telomeres protein (hPOT1) from the single-stranded telomeric DNA overhang is considered to be a consequence of quadruplex formation, induced by the ND compounds.(11) Several ND compounds, in particular those with N-methyl-piperazine end-groups, have shown exceptional antiproliferative potency in a panel of pancreatic cancer cell lines,(11) with a lead compound having typical IC50 values in the range of 100–200 nM. An evaluation of the activity of one of these compounds (4) in a pancreatic cancer xenograft model has revealed significant antitumor activity, with a 50% reduction in tumor volume on intraperitoneal (ip) administration, accompanied by potent inhibition of telomerase activity (in MCF7 breast carcinoma cells).(12) Structure–activity relationships for side chain length variations have subsequently been explored with the aid of two crystal structures of complexes between a 22-mer intramolecular human telomeric quadruplex and N-methyl-piperazine-substituted ND compounds, one of which is compound 4 (Figure 1) and the other is an analogue with longer (−(CH2)4−) side chain linkers.(13a)
    These and other earlier(13b) naphthalene diimide-quadruplex crystal structures have consistently revealed that these ligands bind to the G-quartet surfaces of the parallel form of the human telomeric quadruplex. The crystal structures with N-methyl-piperazine-substituted ND compounds(13a) also show two adjacent side chains firmly positioned in adjacent quadruplex grooves. Solution circular dichroism studies have concurred with the parallel topology assignment.(11) An important feature observed in the earlier cocrystal structure(13a) is that the charged nitrogen atom of one N-methyl-piperazine ring of compound 4 is in direct hydrogen-bonded proximity to a phosphate oxygen group. The N-methyl-piperazine ring on the adjacent side chain also interacts with a phosphate group, albeit indirectly via a network of water molecules in the groove.
    The present report discloses the results of a structure-based design study in which the four positive charges of compound 4 have been modulated by substituting N-methyl-piperazine groups on two of the four side arms of the ND core with more weakly basic groups, with the aim of improving the pharmacological properties of the ND series without compromising quadruplex interaction. We have previously shown that complete removal of cationic groups from ND compounds results in a significant decrease in quadruplex affinity and biological activity,(9) hence the present strategy of modifying just two of the four side arms. We hypothesized that some diminution in the highly cationic nature of these naphthalene diimide compounds could improve cellular uptake and potential tumor distribution properties while retaining quadruplex affinity.
    The morpholine group has been used, not only because it slightly reduces the overall molecular weight of the compounds, but more importantly because it is significantly less basic than the protonated N-methyl-piperazine ring,(14) with a pK of 8.5 compared to that for the latter, of 9.2. Thus it is expected that this would have an effect on the overall polarity and pharmacological availability of the compound. The present study also examines the hypothesis that the presence of four N-methyl-piperazine groups is nonessential for effective quadruplex binding because the morpholine group is of approximately equivalent size and so could be bound in the same region of quadruplex space at the mouth of a quadruplex groove. A structure-based approach has been used to validate this concept in detail, namely that two N-methyl-piperazine groups can be replaced by morpholine ones without affecting the nature of the interactions with a human telomeric quadruplex DNA. The series was further explored with ND compounds having a diversity of noncharged end-groups: methoxy, furan, tetrahydrofuran, or tetrahydropyran. None of these have any basic character, but their size differences have enabled further SAR features to be probed.
    Complementing this analysis, the cellular responses and possible mode of action of the lead morpholine compound has been examined by studying its effects on proliferation, telomerase inhibition, on cellular senescence, and on the transcriptional profile of a number of genes involved in telomere maintenance and DNA damage responses.

    Results

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Compounds 3a–h (Figure 1) were synthesized according to Scheme 1, with the dibromo precursor 1 obtained by a published procedure,(15) using commercially available amines.(16) The methodology is closely similar to that previously reported.(9, 11) A representative synthesis is outlined in Scheme 1. The tetrahydrofuran and tetrahydropyran derivatives are racemic.

    Crystal Structures

    Three ND-quadruplex cocrystal structures have been determined in this study, of complexes A–C (Figures 2–5). The cocrystal structure of compound 3d with the human telomeric 22-mer quadruplex sequence d[AGGG(TTAGGG)3] is shown in Figures 2 and 3a,b. The same sequence was used in the earlier structural studies on both the native sequence(17) and previous ND complexes.(13a) This 2:2 structure (complex A) has a ligand molecule bound at each end of the 5′–5′ quadruplex dimer, stacked over the terminal G-quartets. The two aniline substituents of 3d are both oriented such that they can form intramolecular hydrogen bonds with adjacent carbonyl oxygen atoms (Figure 2b), effectively extending the π–π overlap with the G-quartet. Figure 2b also shows that the chromophore and side chains of compound 3d almost exactly superimposes over the position observed for compound 4 in its cocrystal structure (PDB 3SC8(13a)) with a root-mean-square-deviation (rmsd) of 0.76 Å. This correspondence extends to the orientations of the terminal groups on the side chains. One ring nitrogen atom of the N-methyl-piperazine group in compound 3d (probably the one that is protonated) is directly hydrogen-bonded to a phosphate oxygen atom (Figure 3b), whereas the morpholine ring that is positioned within the adjacent groove does not have any direct hydrogen bonds to the quadruplex backbone.
    A number of water molecules have been located in the quadruplex grooves of complex A and are involved in hydrogen-bonding from the morpholine ring of compound 3d to a network of four water molecules and then to a neighboring phosphate group (Figure 3a), as judged by their intermolecular distances all being <3.1 Å. The groove-bound N-methyl-piperazine ring in this structure is also extensively involved in water-mediated hydrogen-bonding (Figure 3b). This suggests that these water molecules are significant contributors to the stabilization of the side-chains within the quadruplex grooves. Comparison of complex A (Figure 3a) with that of the previously determined complex with compound 4 (Figure 3c) shows that the substitution of the N-methyl-piperazine rings with morpholine ones does not significantly alter either the position or orientation of the end-group, but that its interactions with water molecules are closely similar. It is also notable that the four water molecules involved in bridging between the ring nitrogen atom and the phosphate backbone are conserved between the two structures.
    Two of the complexes (B and C) are the first human telomeric quadruplex-ligand crystal structures to be reported with a 21-mer sequence (Figure 4). The parallel topology of the quadruplex is identical to that in the 22-mer complex A (Figure 5) and to earlier ND complexes.(13a, 13b) This conservation of parallel topology enables rational computer-based drug design to be undertaken with some confidence. The parallel topology has been observed in solution(11) for the 22-mer human telomeric quadruplex complex with compound 4 as well as for a number of dual-function alkylating/reversible binding ND compounds.(8)

    Biophysical Studies

    The ability of compounds 3a–h to stabilize a human telomeric quadruplex was assessed by a high-throughput fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) melting technique.(18) Table 1 also shows melting data obtained with a duplex DNA sequence. This data only provide some indication of quadruplex:duplex selectivity; future competition experiments will provide more detailed information. Table 1 shows that, apart from the tetra-N-methyl-piperazine compound 4, only the compounds containing morpholine rings showed significant telomeric quadruplex stabilization, as well as some binding to the duplex DNA sequence. The dimethoxy compound 3e has a very slight effect on the telomeric quadruplex used here but a large stabilizing effect on HSP90 promoter sequence quadruplexes (which are reported elsewhere(19) to form stable quadruplexes), with ΔTm values of 23.8 and 29.0 °C. The furan, pyranose, and acyclic ether compounds (3b, 3c, and 3e) do not have any effect on telomeric quadruplex or duplex stability. All of the morpholine derivatives produce high Tm changes in the telomeric quadruplex, comparable to that previously noted for compound 4. However compounds 3f and 3g, with an n = 2 −(CH2)n– linker to the morpholine ring, show superior selectivity for quadruplex over duplex DNA compared to the n = 3 compounds.

    Biological Studies

    The antiproliferative activity of the group of nine ND derivatives was assessed using the SRB (sulforhodamine) assay following 96 h exposure to 2-fold serial dilutions of each compound (Table 2) in a panel of cancer cell lines together with a normal fibroblast line. Compound 3a is devoid of significant antiproliferative activity in all except the MIA PaCa-2 and A549 lines although all other compounds in this group (3b, 3c, 3e) had IC50 values in the range of 1–8 μM, with compound 3c in particular showing up to 10-fold selectivity for the renal carcinoma cell line 786-0. In contrast, the morpholine compounds all show sub-μM antiproliferative activity in at least some of the cancer cell lines used, and the two compounds 3d and 3h, with n = 3 −(CH2)n– linkers to the morpholine groups, show particularly potent activity in the MIA PaCa-2 pancreatic carcinoma and A549 lung adenocarcinoma cell lines (IC50 values of 10–20 nM).

    Comparable data for compound 4 has been previously reported.(11, 12) The panel of cancer carcinoma cell lines used includes: A549 (lung), RCC4, and 786-0 (renal), MIA PaCa-2 (pancreatic), and MCF-7 (breast). Data for the two lead di-morpholine compounds has been highlighted.

    The telomerase inhibitory activity of 3a, 3d, 3e, and 3h was assessed in MIA PaCa-2 cells treated with each compound, using the modified TRAP-LIG assay (Figure 6a).(20) No change in the products of telomerase-mediated telomere elongation were apparent at up to 10 μM of each compound, indicating that this group of compounds lacks telomerase inhibitory activity, at least at the dosage levels producing growth inhibitory effects. This is in striking contrast to the potent telomerase inhibition previously found for tetra-substituted ND compounds, with compound 4 having an telEC50 value (the concentration required to reduce telomerase activity by 50%) of 50 nM in breast carcinoma MCF7 cells.(11, 12) A side-by-side comparison of compounds 3d and 4 assessing inhibition of telomerase activity in MIA PaCa-2 cells (Figure 6b) did not show any significant decrease in telomerase activity, again as judged by the lack of change in the elongation product gel ladders. It is noticeable that the intensity of the bands at the higher concentration for both compounds is significantly reduced, suggestive of an effect on telomerase processivity rather than on its enzymatic activity.
    In view of the potent antiproliferative activity of the lead compound 3d, its inactivity in the MIA PaCa-2 cell line against telomerase at concentration levels that produce inhibition of cancer cell growth suggested a more complex mode of action in this line compared with the parent molecules of this quadruplex-stabilizing agent.(9, 10) To further investigate the activity and possible molecular targets of compound 3d, its effects on the transcription of the major human genes, controlling (i) telomerase and telomere maintenance and (ii) DNA damage response, was assessed in MIA PaCa-2 cells using pathway-focused qPCR arrays.
    Dose–response curves were used to guide the choice of compound concentration and time-points for the array experiments (Figure 7a). Exposure to between 5 and 40 nM of compound 3d resulted in titratable growth inhibition with subsequent full recovery of confluent growth at 144 h (Figure 7b). Exposure to 80 nM of 3d resulted in no growth recovery, although cells remained viable, whereas at 160 nM no viable cells could be recovered by 72 h. To explore this response continuum, the transcriptional signature of cells exposed for 24 h to 20, 40, and 80 nM concentrations of 3d, or solvent alone as control, was analyzed as described in Materials and Methods. It was expected that this time point would capture the early transcriptional signature responses to compound challenge that resulted in the differing levels of growth inhibition observed. Complete data sets for the telomere maintenance and DNA damage response pathways are given in Supporting Information Tables S1 and S2, respectively.
    Analysis of 83 genes involved with telomere maintenance revealed modest responses to exposure to compound 3d (Figure 7c). In total, 30 genes were up- or down-regulated compared to controls, to a statistically significant level (P < 0.05, Student’s t test) by 20, 40, or 80 nM of 3d compared with the solvent. However, changes in transcript abundance were modest, with only seven of these genes (MYC, NHP2, PPARG, PRKCB, PTEGES3, RASSF1, and SLX4) showing greater than 2-fold abundance changes (Figure 7d,e). Down-regulation of the genes encoding the telomere end-capping protein POT1 and the telomerase-associated protein PTGES3 (also known as p23) was also observed.
    Various quadruplex-stabilizing agents are known to induce pronounced DNA damage responses.(3, 6, 33) We therefore next assessed the effect of 3d on the transcription of genes associated with DNA damage response and repair pathways. For these pathways, the effect of a cytotoxic dosage of 3d (160 nM) on MIA PaCa-2 cells was also tested to assess the correlation between compound-induced DNA damage and cell killing. Of 83 genes tested, 16 were significantly increased or decreased greater than 2-fold in abundance following exposure to 20, 40, 80, or 160 nM of compound 3d (Figure 8a). Three patterns of transcriptional response were identified within the DNA damage response gene set: (i) seven genes that showed down-regulation only, notably BAX, PARP1, RAD50, and MPG (Figure 8b); (ii) six genes that were down-regulated at subcytotoxic concentrations but up-regulated at toxic concentrations, including CDKN1A, DDIT3, and GADD45G (Figure 8c); (iii) three genes that were up-regulated at sublethal concentrations and down-regulated at 160 nM (Figure 8d). The latter two groups appeared to reflect a dynamic switch in the cellular response from low-level growth inhibition up to 40 nM of 3d to cytostatic then cytotoxic effects at 80 and 160 nM, respectively.
    Although overall genes responsive to DNA damage were far more strongly affected than those in pathways involving telomere maintenance, there was no significant induction of the major DNA damage response or repair pathways such as ATM/CHK1 and ATR/CHK2. Furthermore, there was no apparent induction of the γ-H2AX gene in MIA PaCa-2 cells following treatment with 3d (data not shown), suggesting that any DNA damage induced by 3d may not involve double-stranded breaks (however, because γ-H2AX is regulated at the post-translational level, this conclusion must at present be treated with caution). Instead, the response was dominated by genes with roles in growth arrest and more general stress responses. Notably, CDKN1A, DDIT3, and GADD45G were all strongly down-regulated by the lower concentrations of 3d and strongly up-regulated at cytotoxic concentrations.
    The CDKN1A gene encodes the cyclin-dependent kinase p21WAF1 that induces replicative senescence, which is a well-studied consequence of telomerase inhibition and telomere maintenance disruption.(21) We observed a strong induction of senescence in MIA PaCa-2 cells treated for 7 days with both compound 3d and 4 (Figure 9). Compound 3d was ∼10-fold more potent than 4 as an inducer of cellular senescence. Compounds 3b and 3d behaved in a similar manner to each other, with concentrations of 3–4 nM being sufficient to result in ∼50–60% of cells becoming senescent after this time-course. Together, these data suggest that both ND derivative sets cause growth arrest through induction of senescence but that the route to this precedes through distinct telomerase-dependent (compound 4) and independent (compound 3d) pathways.

    Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The small library of tetra-substituted naphthalene diimides reported here shows a wide range of antiproliferative activity in this particular panel of cancer cell lines. In view of their low level of quadruplex binding, as found in the in vitro FRET assay, the activity of the dicationic compounds 3b, 3c, and 3e is unlikely to involve telomere maintenance disruption via the stabilization of human telomeric quadruplex DNA. However, in the absence of any other evidence, the possibility cannot be excluded that these compounds may be targeting one or more promoter (or mRNA) quadruplexes;(22) for example, renal cancer cells express the hypoxia-inducible factor HIF,(23a) which has a well-characterized quadruplex sequence in its promoter region.(23b, 23c) These and other possible promoter quadruplex targets remain to be explored in subsequent studies.
    The crystal structures reported here, taken together with previous structures of ND tetra-substituted and tetra-cationic complexes,(13) show a consistent pattern of substituent binding in the quadruplex grooves and water-mediated quadruplex-side-chain hydrogen-bonding. This has enabled the conservative substitution of N-methyl-piperazine groups by morpholine ones to be made with confidence because this change does not have any significant effect on the detailed structure of the resulting quadruplex complexes or indeed of the microenvironment of the bound ligands. The prediction from the crystal structures, that the bis-morpholine compound 3d would have quadruplex stabilizing ability comparable to that of the previously described compound 4, is borne out by the FRET data. It can be concluded therefore that the data obtained on the morpholine modified compounds supports the rationale of this study. The slight decrease in ΔTm value for the quadruplex complex with 3d, compared to the behavior of compound 4, is consistent with the reduced basicity of the morpholino group, leading to a reduced electrostatic contribution to stabilization. A key requirement of small molecules in order to demonstrate high-affinity quadruplex binding (accompanied by biological activity), has generally been accepted(4b-4e) as the possession of cationic groups, most commonly attached to flexible side chains. The data on compound 3d (and 3h) show that side chain basicity can be modulated without significant deleterious effects on ability to bind to human telomeric quadruplex DNA yet with significant changes in biological profile.
    The three crystal structures reported here also provide further evidence that bulky small molecules binding to human telomeric intramolecular quadruplexes stabilize the parallel topology, which has been observed in all other cocrystal structures of intramolecular telomeric quadruplex sequences with small molecules, most recently with the alkaloid berberine(24) and with N-methyl mesoporphyrin IX.(25) The latter compound, in common with ND compounds(11) such as 4, also stabilizes the parallel form in solution, as judged by circular dichroism spectra.(26) The parallel telomeric quadruplex topology has now been observed in a variety of crystal forms when bound to a wide range of ligands.(27) This indicates that weak crystal packing forces are unlikely to be the determinants for stabilizing this fold but rather that it is the preferred topology for human telomeric quadruplex complexes with these ligands, especially in a crowded environment such as in a heavily hydrated crystal or in concentrated solution and, by implication, in cellular conditions.(28)
    The profiles of cell growth inhibitory potency shown by compounds 3d and the shorter chain-length compound 3h in a panel of cancer cell lines are superior to that of compound 4, consistent with the prediction of improved pharmacological properties for the former. It is notable that in common with compound 4, both dimorpholine compounds 3d and 3h show selectivity for some of these cancer cell lines when compared to the normal fibroblast line WI-38. Selectivity was found to be greatest for the pancreatic MIA PaCa-2 cell line, ∼20-fold for 3d and ∼200-fold for 3h, suggesting that these compounds could have a useable therapeutic window in vivo. The cellular selectivity and possible therapeutic window does not appear to be directly related to the slightly greater stabilization of duplex DNA shown by the morpholine compounds compared to compound 4. The lack of significant telomeric quadruplex binding shown by the furan and methoxy-containing compounds, suggests that the ability to participate in hydrogen-bonding in the quadruplex grooves as observed in the crystal structures in this series, is a requirement for all four end-groups in these ND compounds.
    MIA PaCa-2 carcinoma cells are well-established to be telomerase-positive and telomere-maintenance defective;(29-31) the present results support the concept that the two effects can be separated, at least in this pancreatic cancer cell line. Remarkably, neither compound 3d and 4 are not inhibitors of telomerase activity in this cell line at the doses relevant to the IC50 values reported here. Compound 4 was previously reported(11) to be a potent telomerase inhibitor in MCF7 breast carcinoma cells, whereas the present findings do not reveal activity in the pancreatic cancer line MIA PaCa-2, suggesting that in the latter other effects such as disruption of the shelterin complex may be more significant, in accord with findings for other potent telomeric quadruplex-binding ligands.(34) This lack of telomerase inhibition is also apparently in contrast to the finding(32) that symmetrically tetra-substituted naphthalene diimides such as compound 4 invoke DNA damage responses in some cell lines(32, 33) (albeit at rather high concentrations) that are closely analogous to those found for a number of other telomeric quadruplex ligands(6) such as the appearance of γ-H2AX foci.(34, 35) By contrast the morpholine compounds 3d and 3h do not appear to induce these particular changes. This is consistent with the pattern of transcriptional changes in DNA damage response genes (Figure 8; Supporting Information Table S2), which revealed no significant transcriptional induction of any of the key components of the six DNA damage response pathways associated with telomere end protection: ATM (ataxia talengiectasia mutated) and ATR (ataxia talengiectasia and Rad3 related) signaling, homologous recombination, and classical and alternative nonhomologous end joining and resection.(36) In contrast, we observed down-regulation of the genes encoding the DNA repair proteins RAD50 and nibrin of the MRN complex, which contributes to several DNA damage responses including nonhomologous end joining, homologous recombination, and ATM and ATR pathways.(33)
    In contrast, genes encoding a number of other markers of cellular stress and the DNA damage response were up-regulated, notably genes encoding the phosphatase protein phosphatase magnesium dependent 1D (PPM1D), growth arrest, and DNA-damage-inducible proteins GADD45A and GADD45G, DNA damage inducible transcript 3 (DDIT3), and cyclin dependent kinase inhibitor 1A (CDKN1A). These findings correspond with several recent studies of quadruplex stabilizing compounds, and it could be interesting to address whether induction of these genes is indicative of quadruplex stabilization-mediated stress. For example, PPM1D has recently been shown to be activated by the quadruplex stabilizing triazine derivative 12459 in the lung fibroblast cell line A549, resulting in arrest of typical DNA damage signaling at pro-apoptotic concentrations of this compound.(37) The observed induction of PPM1D at concentrations of 3d that were cytotoxic could correspond to a similar cellular response to quadruplex stabilization in MIA PaCa-2 cells. DDIT3 acts as a dominant negative transcriptional regulator, mediating G1 cell cycle arrest in response to DNA damage, ER stress, hypoxia, and starvation and has also been linked to apoptosis in certain cell types.(38, 39)CDKN1A encodes p21, a central mediator of cell growth arrest and senescence.(40) The strong induction of this gene is consistent with the morphological observation of a pronounced increase in senescence in 3d-treated MIA PaCa-2 cells (Figure 9). To our knowledge, this is the first pathway-based transcriptional analysis of a G4 stabilizing agent in a pancreatic cell line and will provide a useful reference for further study of these compounds.
    The qPCR expression data is suggestive of cell cycle checkpoint arrest that is not purely mediated by changes in telomere organization, although the moderate changes in the expression levels of several telomere-associated genes is consistent with their involvement in the arrest of cancer cell growth. It is also notable that expression of the PARP (poly (ADP-ribose) polymerase) gene is down-regulated; the PARP protein is involved in the repair of single-strand breaks, and its inhibition by small molecules is currently the subject of clinical trials in several cancers.(41) The dose-dependent down-regulation of PARP expression observed here may thus contribute to the overall antiproliferative effects of compound 3d and to its anticancer effects in vivo. There is also evidence that telomere maintenance in pancreatic cancer cells can involve nontelomerase mechanisms (the so-called alternative lengthening of telomeres, ALT pathway).(42) Several G-quadruplex binding agents have been shown(43) to have activity, in established ALT cell lines, although this has not been explored for the present compounds and we cannot exclude the possibility without further study that the potent effects on pancreatic cell proliferation observed here are at least in part due to targeting of the ALT process. Very recent studies(44) on the role of telomerase in several tumor models have highlighted its genetic complexity and that pure telomerase inhibition may be bypassed by ALT activation, supporting the value of studying those compounds which have broad effects against telomere maintenance mechanisms in cancer cells.
    Because of the G-rich nature of telomeric sequences, the cellular consequences of G-quadruplex stabilization of compound 3d were initially expected to proceed through inhibition of telomerase function, leading to disruption of telomere maintenance.(5, 7, 9-12) The data presented here adds to a growing body of evidence that quadruplex stabilization by small molecules can lead to cell line specific growth arrest of cancer cells through multiple, often nonmutually exclusive events such as DNA damage, leading to a range of effects including check point arrest, inhibition of rRNA biogenesis, oncogenic promoter stabilization and inhibition, and autophagy.(6a, 22, 45-47) The potent stabilization of the two HSP90 promoter quadruplexes by several of the morpholine compounds may also indicate that the HSP90 gene is itself a target.(19) Which process and which target(s) are relevant to a particular compound may depend on the exact location, accessibility, and topology of the stabilized quadruplex tracts in a particular cell type. The exact consequences and site of action of quadruplex stabilization mediated by compound 3d, and the basis for its lack of telomerase inhibition compared to compounds such as 4 will be the subject of further biological and pharmacological studies.

    Materials and Methods

    Chemistry

    All chemicals, reagents, and solvents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, Alfa Aesar, Lancaster Synthesis, and Fluorochem (UK) and used without further purification. Solvents were supplied by VWR and Fisher Scientific. Column chromatography was performed using BDH silica gel (BDH 153325P). HPLC analysis was carried out with a Gilson apparatus combining a 322 pump and an Agilent 1100 series detector, using a C18 5 μ (100 mm × 4.6 mm) column (41622271 (W), YMC, Japan), at a flow of 1 mL/min. Preparative HPLC was carried out with a Gilson apparatus combining a 322 pump and a UV/vis-155 detector with detection at 280 nm, using a C18 5 μ (100 mm × 20 mm) column (201022272) (W), YMC, Japan, at a flow of 20 mL/min. Water and methanol with 0.1% formic acid were used as solvents for HPLC. For the purification of compounds 3d and 3f–h, the following method was used: 100% aqueous solution for 5 min after injection, then gradually decreased to 60% aqueous solution over 25 min. To obtain the free amines of compounds 3a–h, each final compound was dissolved in MeOH and filtered through a basified plug of silica with a mobile phase of 98:2 (MeOH:Et3N). MeOH and Et3N were subsequently evaporated under reduced pressure. For compounds 3a–c and 3e, the following method was used: 100% aqueous solution for 2 min after injection, gradually decreased to 20% aqueous solution over 17 min. For the HPLC purity analysis of compounds 3a–h, the method used was: 100% aqueous solution for 5 min after injection, to 60% w/v aqueous solution over 18 min as well as 100% aqueous for 5 min after injection, to 60% w/v aqueous over 43 min. Purity for final compounds was greater than 95% (HPLC, 280 nm). NMR spectra were recorded at 400 MHz (1H NMR) or 500 MHz (13C NMR) on a Bruker spectrometer in CDCl3 (with 0.05% TMS, Cambridge Isotope Laboratories, USA). NMR spectra were analyzed with MestReC 4.5.6.0 with chemical shifts using TMS as a standard (δ = 0 ppm). NMR multiplicity abbreviations are s (singlet), bs (broad singlet), d (doublet), t (triplet), q (quartet), 5q (quintet), and m (multiplet). Coupling constants J are reported as observed in hertz (Hz). High resolution mass spectra (HRMS) were measured on a Micromass Q-TTOF Ultima global tandem mass spectrometer run under electrospray ionization (ESI), and processed using the MassLab 3.2 software. For compounds 2a–f, no 13C NMRs were obtained due to solubility issues.
    Compound 1 was prepared according to literature procedures.(15) Analytical data and 1H and 13C NMR spectra matched literature values.
    Compounds 2a–f were prepared according to general procedure A(16) and are reported in the Supporting Information.
    General procedure B. Compounds 3a–h were prepared according to general procedure B.

    Crystallography

    The human telomeric DNA sequences used for crystallization trials, d(GGG[TTAGGG]3) (21-mer) and d(AGGG[TTAGGG]3) (22-mer), were purchased from MWG (Germany) (HPLC purified). Both DNA sequences were annealed at 2.2 mM in 20 mM potassium cacodylate (pH 6.5) and 50 mM potassium chloride. The annealing procedure involved heating the buffered DNA oligonucleotides to 90 °C for 3 min followed by slow cooling to room temperature overnight. For crystallization trials, the DNA was used at a concentration of 1.8 mM plus an equimolar quantity of compound 3d or 4. Crystals of complexes A–C were grown in standard hanging drops, composed of 0.7 μL of the complex solution plus an equal volume of a crystallization reagent. Crystals of complex A were grown at 20 °C using a crystallization reagent composed of 15% w/v PEG400, 100 mM lithium chloride, 100 mM sodium chloride, 100 mM potassium bromide, and 50 mM sodium cacodylate (pH 6.5). Crystals of complexes B and C were grown at 20 and 12 °C, respectively, using a crystallization reagent composed of 15% w/v PEG400, 150 mM sodium chloride, and 50 mM sodium cacodylate (pH 6.5). Before flash freezing in liquid nitrogen, all crystals were cryoprotected in a solution composed of the appropriate crystallization reagent supplemented with 15% w/v glycerol.
    Diffraction data were collected at the Diamond Light Source Synchrotron (UK) on Beamline I04. Data were processed and scaled using Xia2 and Scala software in the CCP4 package.(48) All three complexes were solved by molecular replacement using the PHASER program,(49) using a previously reported 22-mer-ND crystal structure(13a) as a search model. All nonguanine residues and solvent molecules were removed from the initial search model. Initial (Fo – Fc and 2Fo – Fc) electron density maps for all three complexes showed clear density for the G-quartets, potassium ions, and the majority of the loop regions. Importantly, residual electron density above the 3′-G-quartet could be seen for all three complexes, into which the appropriate ND compounds could be easily fitted. Model building and restrained refinement were performed using the Coot(50) and Refmac5(51) programs, respectively. Initial geometric parameters for compounds 3d and 4 were obtained using the PRODRG server.(52) Crystallographic data, collection data, and refinement statistics are shown in Table 3. Structure factors and coordinates for complexes A–C have been deposited in the Protein Data Bank. Structures were drawn using the CHIMERA(53) and PYMOL programs.(54)

    FRET Assay

    The ability of the naphthalene diimide compounds to stabilize DNA sequences was investigated using a fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) assay modified to be used as a high-throughput screen in a 96-well format.(18) Several quadruplex sequences were studied (the human telomeric G-quadruplex DNA sequence 5′-FAM-d(GGG[TTAGGG]3)-TAMRA-3′ and the duplex sequence 5′-FAM-dTATAGCTATA-HEG-TATAGCTATA-TAMRA-3′ (HEG linker: [(−CH2-CH2-O−)6])), as well as two overlapping sequences from the HSP90 promoter region (HSP90a and HSP90b):

    • HSP90a: 5′-FAM-d(GGGCCAAAGGGAAGGGGTGGG) -TAMRA-3′

    • HSP90b: 5′-FAM-d(GGGCGGGCCAAAGGGAAGGGG) -TAMRA-3′

    The labeled oligonucleotides have attached to them the donor fluorophore FAM, 6-carboxyfluorescein, and the acceptor fluorophore TAMRA, 6-carboxytetramethylrhodamine. The FRET probe sequences were diluted from stock to the correct concentration (400 nM) in a 60 mM potassium cacodylate buffer (pH 7.4) and then annealed by heating to 85 °C for 10 min, followed by cooling to room temperature in the heating block. The compound was stored as a 10 mM stock solution in DMSO; final solutions (at 2× concentration) were prepared using 10 mM HCl in the initial 1:10 dilution, after which 60 mM potassium cacodylate buffer (pH 7.4) was used in all subsequent steps. The maximum HCl concentration in the reaction volume (at a ligand concentration of 20 μM) is thus 200 μM, well within the range of the buffer used. Relevant controls were also performed to check for interference with the assay. Then 96-well plates (MJ Research, Waltham, MA) were prepared by aliquoting 50 μL of the annealed DNA into each well, followed by 50 μL of the compound solutions. Measurements were made on a DNA Engine Opticon (MJ Research) with excitation at 450–495 nm and detection at 515–545 nm. Fluorescence readings were taken at intervals of 0.5 °C in the range 30–100 °C, with a constant temperature being maintained for 30 s prior to each reading to ensure a stable value. Final analysis of the data was carried out using a script written in the program Origin 7.0 (OriginLab Corp., Northampton, MA). The advanced curve-fitting function in Origin 7.0 was used for calculation of ΔTm values. All determinations were performed in triplicate or better. ESDs in ΔTm are ±0.1 °C.

    Cell Culture and Cytotoxicity Testing

    Human cancer cell lines, MCF7 (breast), A549 (lung), MIA PaCa-2, and HPAC (pancreatic), RCC4, and 786-0 renal, and the somatic human cell line WI-38 (lung fibroblast) were purchased from ATCC. Cell lines were maintained in appropriate medium supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (Invitrogen, UK), 2 mM l-glutamine (Invitrogen, Netherlands), and other components as specified by the suppliers. Cell lines were maintained at 37 °C, 5% CO2 and routinely passaged. Drugs were dissolved in DMSO and filtered through 0.22 μm pore-size filter units before addition to cell line appropriate media. Cellular growth inhibition was measured using the sulforhodamine B (SRB) assay in 96-well plates as described previously.(10, 11) Then 50% inhibitory concentrations (IC50) were determined by taking the mean absorbance at 540 nm for each drug concentration expressed as a percentage of the absorbance of untreated control wells.
    For qRT-PCR analysis, MIA PaCa-2 cells were seeded to a density equivalent to that used for IC50 determinations in T75 culture flasks and grown for 24 h in 10 mL of DMEM to allow attachment before addition of compound 3d to the culture medium. Following compound exposure, cells were washed twice in PBS, harvested by trypsinisation, collected by centrifugation (300g, 5 min, 4 °C) and resuspended in RLT buffer (Qiagen). Samples were homogenized using QIAshredder spin columns and stored at −80 °C prior to RNA extraction. Three biological replicates were performed on separate days.

    Determination of Cellular Telomerase Activity

    Telomerase activity was determined using the TRAP-LIG assay,(22) a modified telomere repeat amplification protocol that ensures that there is no carryover of ligand into the second PCR step of the assay. Briefly, 1 μg of protein from untreated and treated cells were incubated with TS forward primer (0.1 μg of 5′-AAT CCG TCG AGC AGA GTT-3′) at 30 °C for 10 min to allow the initial elongation to take place. Elongated products were purified using the QIAquick nucleotide purification kit (Qiagen) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Eluted samples were freeze-dried and redissolved in PCR grade water. Redissolved PCR products were subjected to amplification in master mix containing ACX reverse primer (1 μM, 5′-GCG CGG [CTTACC]3 CTA ACC-3′), TS forward primer (0.1 μg), TRAP buffer, BSA (5 μg), 0.5 mM dNTPs, and 2U RedHot TAQ polymerase (ABgene, UK) for 35 cycles of 94 °C for 30 s, 61 °C for 1 min, and at 72 °C for 1 min. Samples were separated by PAGE and visualized with SYBR green (Aldrich). Positive controls used cells that were not treated with compound and negative controls omitted (telomerase-containing) protein extract.

    Transcriptional Analysis

    The expression of (i) 83 key human genes involved in telomere replication and maintenance and (ii) 83 human genes involved in DNA damage signaling responses was assessed using PCR arrays (SABiosciences). Total RNA was extracted from approximately 1 × 107 MIA PaCa-2 cells treated for 24 h with compound 3d, using the RNeasy kit (Qiagen) with on-column DNaseI treatment to remove residual genomic DNA. The quality of the harvested RNA was confirmed by nanodrop spectroscopy and by analysis with a human RT2 RNA QC PCR array. First-strand cDNA synthesis was performed with the RT2 first strand kit and qPCR was carried out using the RT2 qPCR master mix (Qiagen) using 0.5 μg of total RNA per array plate in a Stratagene MX-3000P instrument (Agilent, USA). Relative gene expression was determined by the ΔΔCT method using the web-based RT2 Profiler PCR Array Data Analysis software (SABiosciences). Data were normalized to the geometric mean of five housekeeping genes (RPLP10, β-actin, B2M, GAPDH, and HPRT1).

    Senescence Staining

    Senescence detection and quantification experiments were carried out using the Senescence β-galactosidase staining kit (Cell Signaling Technology, MA, USA) according to the manufacturer’s protocol. Briefly, 1 × 105 cells were seeded in 6-well plates in 2 mL of medium supplemented with the test compound and incubated for 24 h. Cells were washed (2 mL of PBS), fixed (2% formaldehyde and 2% glutaraldehyde in PBS, 15 min, room temperature), and washed (2 × 2 mL PBS) before staining overnight. Senescent cells, detected by their blue pigmentation, were counted using a light microscope.

      1b
      Quadruplex DNA: sequence, topology and structure
      Burge, Sarah; Parkinson, Gary N.; Hazel, Pascale; Todd, Alan K.; Neidle, Stephen
      Nucleic Acids Research (2006), 34 (19), 5402-5415CODEN: NARHAD; ISSN:0305-1048. (Oxford University Press)
      A review. G-quadruplexes are higher-order DNA and RNA structures formed from G-rich sequences that are built around tetrads of hydrogen-bonded guanine bases. Potential quadruplex sequences have been identified in G-rich eukaryotic telomeres, and more recently in non-telomeric genomic DNA, e.g. in nuclease-hypersensitive promoter regions. The natural role and biol. validation of these structures is starting to be explored, and there is particular interest in them as targets for therapeutic intervention. This survey focuses on the folding and structural features on quadruplexes formed from telomeric and non-telomeric DNA sequences, and examines fundamental aspects of topol. and the emerging relationships with sequence. Emphasis is placed on information from the high-resoln. methods of x-ray crystallog. and NMR, and their scope and current limitations are discussed. Such information, together with biol. insights, will be important for the discovery of drugs targeting quadruplexes from particular genes.

      Human telomeric G-quadruplex: structures of DNA and RNA sequences
      Phan, Anh Tuan
      FEBS Journal (2010), 277 (5), 1107-1117CODEN: FJEOAC; ISSN:1742-464X. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      A review. Telomeres play an important role in cellular aging and cancer. Human telomeric DNA and RNA G-rich sequences are capable of forming a 4-stranded structure, known as the G-quadruplex. Such a structure might be important for telomere biol. and a good target for drug design. Here, the author describes the structural diversity or conservation of DNA and RNA human telomeric G-quadruplexes, discusses structural views on targeting these G-quadruplexes, and presents some future challenges for structural studies.

      DNA secondary structures: stability and function of structures
      Bochman, Matthew L.; Paeschke, Katrin; Zakian, Virginia A.
      Nature Reviews Genetics (2012), 13 (11), 770-780CODEN: NRGAAM; ISSN:1471-0056. (Nature Publishing Group)
      A review. In addn. to the canonical double helix, DNA can fold into various other inter- and intramol. secondary structures. Although many such structures were long thought to be in vitro artifacts, bioinformatics demonstrates that DNA sequences capable of forming these structures are conserved throughout evolution, suggesting the existence of non-B-form DNA in vivo. In addn., genes whose products promote formation or resoln. of these structures are found in diverse organisms, and a growing body of work suggests that the resoln. of DNA secondary structures is crit. for genome integrity. This Review focuses on emerging evidence relating to the characteristics of G-quadruplex structures and the possible influence of such structures on genomic stability and cellular processes, such as transcription.

      (a) Müller, S.; Kumari, S.; Rodriguez, R.; Balasubramanian, S. Small-molecule-mediated G-quadruplex isolation from human cells Nature Chem. 2010, 2, 1095– 1098
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2a
      Small-molecule-mediated G-quadruplex isolation from human cells
      Muller Sebastian; Kumari Sunita; Rodriguez Raphael; Balasubramanian Shankar
      Nature chemistry (2010), 2 (12), 1095-8 ISSN:.
      Nucleic acids containing stretches of tandem guanines can fold into four-stranded structures called G-quadruplexes. The existence of such sequences in genomic DNA suggests the occurrence of these motifs in cells, with potential implications in a number of biological processes relevant to cancer. Small molecules have proven to be valuable tools to dissect cell circuitry. Here, we describe a synthetic small molecule derived from an N,N'-bis(2-quinolinyl)pyridine-2,6-dicarboxamide, which is designed to mediate the selective isolation of G-quadruplex nucleic acids. The methodology was successfully applied to a range of DNA and RNA G-quadruplexes in vitro. We demonstrate the general applicability of the method by isolating telomeric DNA-containing G-quadruplex motifs from cells. We show that telomeres are targets for the probe, providing further evidence of the formation of G-quadruplexes in human cells.

      2b
      Quantitative visualization of DNA G-quadruplex structures in human cells
      Biffi, Giulia; Tannahill, David; McCafferty, John; Balasubramanian, Shankar
      Nature Chemistry (2013), 5 (3), 182-186CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Four-stranded G-quadruplex nucleic acid structures are of great interest as their high thermodn. stability under near-physiol. conditions suggests that they could form in cells. Here we report the generation and application of an engineered, structure-specific antibody employed to quant. visualize DNA G-quadruplex structures in human cells. We show explicitly that G-quadruplex formation in DNA is modulated during cell-cycle progression and that endogenous G-quadruplex DNA structures can be stabilized by a small-mol. ligand. Together these findings provide substantive evidence for the formation of G-quadruplex structures in the genome of mammalian cells and corroborate the application of stabilizing ligands in a cellular context to target G-quadruplexes and intervene with their function.

      3a
      Inhibition of telomerase by G-quartet DNA structures
      Zahler, Alan M.; Williamson, James R.; Cech, Thomas R.; Prescott, David M.
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (1991), 350 (6320), 718-20CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836.
      The capacity of the different folded forms of telomeric DNA to serve as primers for Oxytricha nova telomerase in vitro was studied. The formation of the K+-stabilized guanine (G)-quartet structure in a primer inhibited its use by telomerase. Furthermore, the octanucleotide, T4G4, which does not fold, was a better primer than (T4G4)2, which can form a foldback structure. It was concluded that telomerase does not require any folding of its DNA primer. The folding of telomeric DNA into G-quartet structures appears to influence the extent of telomere elongation in vitro and may therefore act as a neg. regulator of elongation in vivo.

      Inhibition of Human Telomerase by a G-Quadruplex-Interactive Compound
      Sun, Daekyu; Thompson, Brian; Cathers, Brian E.; Salazar, Miguel; Kerwin, Sean M.; Trent, John O.; Jenkins, Terence C.; Neidle, Stephen; Hurley, Laurence H.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (1997), 40 (14), 2113-2116CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      Human telomerase has been proposed as a novel and potentially highly selective target for antitumor drug design since approx. 85-90% of all human cancers are pos. for telomerase, both in cultured tumor cells and primary tumor tissue, whereas most somatic cells appear to lack detectable levels of telomerase. We have initiated a structure-based approach to discovering non-nucleoside compds. that will selectively inhibit human telomerase by targeting the nucleic acid structures, such as G-quadruplexes, that may be assocd. with human telomeres or telomerase. In this report we first demonstrate inhibition of human telomerase by the 2,6-diamidoanthraquinone (I). We also show by 1H-NMR the stabilization of a G-quadruplex by I and, finally, provide evidence that this compd. inhibits the telomerase enzyme by a mechanism consistent with interaction with G-quadruplex structures.

      4a
      Physiological relevance of telomeric G-quadruplex formation: a potential drug target
      Oganesian, Liana; Bryan, Tracy M.
      BioEssays (2007), 29 (2), 155-165CODEN: BIOEEJ; ISSN:0265-9247. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
      A review. The concept of a G-quartet, a unique structural arrangement intrinsic to guanine-rich DNA, was first introduced by Gellert and colleagues over 40 years ago. For decades, it has been uncertain whether the G-quartet and the structure that it gives rise to, the G-quadruplex, are purely in vitro phenomena. Nevertheless, the presence of signature G-rich motifs in the eukaryotic genome, and the plethora of proteins that bind to, modify or resolve this nucleic acid structure in vitro have provided circumstantial evidence for its physiol. relevance. More recently, direct visualization of G-quadruplex DNA at native telomeres was achieved, bolstering the evidence for its existence in the cell. Furthermore, G-quadruplex folded telomeric DNA has been found to perturb telomere function and to impede the action of telomerase, an enzyme overexpressed in >85% of human cancers, hence opening up a novel avenue for cancer therapy in the form of G-quadruplex stabilizing agents.

      Quadruplex DNA: a promising drug target for the medicinal inorganic chemist
      Ralph, Stephen F.
      Current Topics in Medicinal Chemistry (Sharjah, United Arab Emirates) (2011), 11 (5), 572-590CODEN: CTMCCL; ISSN:1568-0266. (Bentham Science Publishers Ltd.)
      A review. Compds. that can bind to and stabilize quadruplex DNA structures in telomeres, or induce formation of such structures from ssDNA, represent an attractive general approach to the treatment of cancer. Until recently most effort in this area has been directed towards the synthesis of org. compds. for this purpose. More recently there has been growing recognition that metal complexes offer a no. of potential advantages for the prepn. of lead complexes that bind with high affinity and selectivity for quadruplex DNA. This review seeks to discuss the work that has been reported in this area to date. While most early studies focused on metal complexes of porphyrin ligands, during the past 4 years there has been a dramatic increase in the no. of papers in the literature examg. the potential of mononuclear complexes of a variety of other ligands, particularly Schiff base ligands and those based on phenanthroline, as quadruplex DNA binders and telomerase inhibitors. In addn., there has been growing interest in exploiting supramol. chem. to prep. novel multinuclear complexes that bind to this new drug target.

      Small-molecule-induced DNA damage identifies alternative DNA structures in human genes
      Rodriguez, Raphael; Miller, Kyle M.; Forment, Josep V.; Bradshaw, Charles R.; Nikan, Mehran; Britton, Sebastien; Oelschlaegel, Tobias; Xhemalce, Blerta; Balasubramanian, Shankar; Jackson, Stephen P.
      Nature Chemical Biology (2012), 8 (3), 301-310CODEN: NCBABT; ISSN:1552-4450. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Guanine-rich DNA sequences that can adopt non-Watson-Crick structures in vitro are prevalent in the human genome. Whether such structures normally exist in mammalian cells has, however, been the subject of active research for decades. Here we show that the G-quadruplex-interacting drug pyridostatin promotes growth arrest in human cancer cells by inducing replication- and transcription-dependent DNA damage. A chromatin immunopptn. sequencing anal. of the DNA damage marker γH2AX provided the genome-wide distribution of pyridostatin-induced sites of damage and revealed that pyridostatin targets gene bodies contg. clusters of sequences with a propensity for G-quadruplex formation. As a result, pyridostatin modulated the expression of these genes, including the proto-oncogene SRC. We obsd. that pyridostatin reduced SRC protein abundance and SRC-dependent cellular motility in human breast cancer cells, validating SRC as a target of this drug. Our unbiased approach to define genomic sites of action for a drug establishes a framework for discovering functional DNA-drug interactions.

      Quinone Methides Tethered to Naphthalene Diimides as Selective G-Quadruplex Alkylating Agents
      Di Antonio, Marco; Doria, Filippo; Richter, Sara N.; Bertipaglia, Carolina; Mella, Mariella; Sissi, Claudia; Palumbo, Manlio; Freccero, Mauro
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2009), 131 (36), 13132-13141CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      We have developed novel G-quadruplex (G-4) ligand/alkylating hybrid structures, tethering the naphthalene diimide moiety to quaternary ammonium salts of Mannich bases, as quinone-methide precursors, activatable by mild thermal digestion (40 °C). The bis-substituted naphthalene diimides were efficiently synthesized, and their reactivity as activatable bis-alkylating agents was investigated in the presence of thiols and amines in aq. buffered solns. The electrophilic intermediate, quinone-methide, involved in the alkylation process was trapped, in the presence of Et vinyl ether, in a hetero Diels-Alder [4 + 2] cycloaddn. reaction, yielding a substituted 2-ethoxychroman. The DNA recognition and alkylation properties of these new derivs. were investigated by gel electrophoresis, CD, and enzymic assays. The alkylation process occurred preferentially on the G-4 structure in comparison to other DNA conformations. By dissecting reversible recognition and alkylation events, we found that the reversible process is a prerequisite to DNA alkylation, which in turn reinforces the G-quadruplex structural rearrangement.

      Near-IR Core-Substituted Naphthalenediimide Fluorescent Chemosensors for Zinc Ions: Ligand Effects on PET and ICT Channels
      Lu, Xinyu; Zhu, Weihong; Xie, Yongshu; Li, Xin; Gao, Yuan; Li, Fuyou; Tian, He
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2010), 16 (28), 8355-8364, S8355/1-S8355/23CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Near-IR (NIR) emission can offer distinct advantages for both in vitro and in vivo biol. applications. Two NIR fluorescent turn-on sensors N,N'-di-n-butyl-2-(N-{2-[bis(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)amino]ethyl})-6-(N-piperidinyl)naphthalene-1,4,5,8-tetracarboxylic acid bisimide and N,N'-di-n-butyl-2-[N,N,N'-tri(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)amino]ethyl-6-(N-piperidinyl)naphthalene-1,4,5,8-tetracarboxylic acid bisimide (PND and PNT) for Zn2+ based on naphthalenediimide fluorophore are reported. The authors' strategy was to choose core-substituted naphthalenediimide (NDI) as a novel NIR fluorophore and N,N-di(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)ethane-1,2-diamine (DPEA) or N,N,N'-tri(pyridin-2-ylmethyl)ethane-1,2-diamine (TPEA) as the receptor, resp., to improve the selectivity to Zn2+. In the case of PND, the negligible shift in absorption and emission spectra is strongly suggestive that the secondary nitrogen atom (directly connected to the NDI moiety, N1) is little disturbed with Zn2+. The fluorescence enhancement of PND with Zn2+ titrn. is dominated with a typical photoinduced electron-transfer (PET) process. In contrast, the N1 atom for PNT can participate in the coordination of Zn2+ ion, diminishing the electron delocalization of the NDI moiety and resulting in intramol. charge-transfer (ICT) disturbance. For PNT, the distinct blue shift in both absorbance and fluorescence is indicative of a combination of PET and ICT processes, which unexpectedly decreases the sensitivity to Zn2+. Due to the differential binding mode caused by the ligand effect, PND shows excellent selectivity to Zn2+ over other metal ions, with a larger fluorescent enhancement centered at 650 nm. Also both PND and PNT were successfully used to image intracellular Zn2+ ions in the living KB cells.

      Crystal structure of parallel quadruplexes from human telomeric DNA
      Parkinson, Gary N.; Lee, Michael P. H.; Neidle, Stephen
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2002), 417 (6891), 876-880CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Telomeric ends of chromosomes, which comprise noncoding repeat sequences of guanine-rich DNA, are fundamental in protecting the cell from recombination and degrdn. Disruption of telomere maintenance leads to eventual cell death, which can be exploited for therapeutic intervention in cancer. Telomeric DNA sequences can form four-stranded (quadruplex) structures, which may be involved in the structure of telomere ends. Here we describe the crystal structure of a quadruplex formed from four consecutive human telomeric DNA repeats and grown at a K+ concn. that approximates its intracellular concn. K+ ions are obsd. in the structure. The folding and appearance of the DNA in this intramol. quadruplex is fundamentally different from the published Na+-contg. quadruplex structures. All four DNA strands are parallel, with the three linking trinucleotide loops positioned on the exterior of the quadruplex core, in a propeller-like arrangement. The adenine in each TTA linking trinucleotide loop is swung back so that it intercalates between the two thymines. This DNA structure suggests a straightforward path for telomere folding and unfolding, as well as ways in which it can recognize telomere-assocd. proteins.

      A G-quadruplex telomere targeting agent produces p16-associated senescence and chromosomal fusions in human prostate cancer cells
      Incles, Christopher M.; Schultes, Christoph M.; Kempski, Helena; Koehler, Heike; Kelland, Lloyd R.; Neidle, Stephen
      Molecular Cancer Therapeutics (2004), 3 (10), 1201-1206CODEN: MCTOCF; ISSN:1535-7163. (American Association for Cancer Research)
      The trisubstituted acridine deriv. BRACO-19 has been designed to interact with and stabilize the quadruplex DNA structures that can be formed by folding of the single-stranded repeats at the 3' end of human telomeres. We suggest that the BRACO-19 complex inhibits the catalytic function of telomerase in human cancer cells and also destabilizes the telomerase-telomere capping complex so that cells enter senescence.       G-quadruplexes in promoters throughout the human genome
      Huppert, Julian L.; Balasubramanian, Shankar
      Nucleic Acids Research (2007), 35 (2), 406-413CODEN: NARHAD; ISSN:0305-1048. (Oxford University Press)
      Certain G-rich DNA sequences readily form four-stranded structures called G-quadruplexes. These sequence motifs are located in telomeres as a repeated unit, and elsewhere in the genome, where their function is currently unknown. It has been proposed that G-quadruplexes may be directly involved in gene regulation at the level of transcription. In support of this hypothesis, we show that the promoter regions (1 kb upstream of the transcription start site TSS) of genes are significantly enriched in quadruplex motifs relative to the rest of the genome, with >40% of human gene promoters contg. one or more quadruplex motif. Furthermore, these promoter quadruplexes strongly assoc. with nuclease hypersensitive sites identified throughout the genome via biochem. measurement. Regions of the human genome that are both nuclease hypersensitive and within promoters show a remarkable (230-fold) enrichment of quadruplex elements, compared to the rest of the genome. These quadruplex motifs identified in promoter regions also show an interesting structural bias towards more stable forms. These observations support the proposal that promoter G-quadruplexes are directly involved in the regulation of gene expression.

      Direct evidence for a G-quadruplex in a promoter region and its targeting with a small molecule to repress c-MYC transcription
      Siddiqui-Jain, Adam; Grand, Cory L.; Bearss, David J.; Hurley, Laurence H.
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2002), 99 (18), 11593-11598CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
      The nuclease hypersensitivity element III1 upstream of the P1 promoter of c-MYC controls 85-90% of the transcriptional activation of this gene. We have demonstrated that the purine-rich strand of the DNA in this region can form two different intramol. G-quadruplex structures, only one of which seems to be biol. relevant. This biol. relevant structure is the kinetically favored chairform G-quadruplex, which is destabilized when mutated with a single G → A transition, resulting in a 3-fold increase in basal transcriptional activity of the c-MYC promoter. The cationic porphyrin TMPyP4, which has been shown to stabilize this G-quadruplex structure, is able to suppress further c-MYC transcriptional activation. These results provide compelling evidence that a specific G-quadruplex structure formed in the c-MYC promoter region functions as a transcriptional repressor element. Furthermore, we establish the principle that c-MYC transcription can be controlled by ligand-mediated G-quadruplex stabilization.

      Telomere dynamics and genome stability in the human pancreatic tumor cell line MIAPaCa-2
      Skrobot Vidacek N; Cukusic A; Ferenac Kis M; Ivankovic M; Jevtov I; Mrsic S; Rubelj I
      Cytogenetic and genome research (2007), 119 (1-2), 60-7 ISSN:.
      Telomeres are specialized structures found at the ends of eukaryotic chromosomes serving as guardians of genome stability. In normal cells telomeres shorten with each cell division, but immortal cells undergoing multiple divisions constantly have to maintain telomere lengths above a critical level. This is accomplished either through expression of telomerase or the alternative recombination pathway (ALT). In the present study, we analyzed telomere dynamics of the telomerase positive human pancreatic tumor cell line MIAPaCa-2. The cells demonstrated genomic instability with a high frequency of chromosomal aberrations resulting in differences between individual karyotypes within the same cell population. The telomeres were short when compared with normal human fibroblasts, and about 39% of the chromosome ends did not have detectable telomere repeats as demonstrated by PNA-FISH. In many cases telomere signals were missing even when sister chromatids were strongly labeled. In addition, we used an internal PNA probe specific for the X chromosome, present in a single copy in these cells, in order to follow telomere dynamics on individual chromatids. High heterogeneity in telomere signals among individual X chromosomes as well as between their sister chromatids suggested sudden and stochastic loss or gain of telomere repeats. Such constant genomic instability often results in apoptosis and death of a fraction of cells present in the culture at all times. We discuss possible molecular mechanisms that may explain this observed telomere heterogeneity and possible adaptive repair mechanisms by which these cells maintain their chromosomes in order to survive such extreme and permanent genomic instability.

      CHOP is implicated in programmed cell death in response to impaired function of the endoplasmic reticulum
      Zinszner, Helene; Kuroda, Masahiko; Wang, XiaoZhong; Batchvarova, Nikoleta; Lightfoot, Richard T.; Remotti, Helen; Stevens, James L.; Ron, David
      Genes & Development (1998), 12 (7), 982-995CODEN: GEDEEP; ISSN:0890-9369. (Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory Press)
      Cellular stress, particularly in response to toxic and metabolic insults that perturb function of the endoplasmic reticulum (ER stress), is a powerful inducer of the transcription factor CHOP. The role of CHOP in the response of cells to injury assocd. with ER stress was examd. in a murine deficiency model obtained by homologous recombination at the chop gene. Compared with the wild type, mouse embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs) derived from chop -/- animals exhibited significantly less programmed cell death when challenged with agents that perturb ER function. A similar deficit in programmed cells death in response to ER stress was also obsd. in MEFs that lack CHOP's major dimerization partner, C/EBPβ, implicating the CHOP-C/EBP pathway in programmed cell death. An animal model for studying the effects of chop on the response to ER stress was developed. It entailed exposing mice with defined chop genotypes to a single sublethal i.p. injection of tunicamycin and resulted in a severe illness characterized by transient renal insufficiency. In chop +/+ and chop +/- mice this was assocd. with the early expression of CHOP in the proximal tubules followed by the development of a histol. picture similar to the human condition known as acute tubular necrosis, a process that resolved by cellular regeneration. In the chop -/- animals, in spite of the severe impairment in renal function, evidence of cellular death in the kidney was reduced compared with the wild type. The proximal tubule epithelium of chop -/- animals exhibited fourfold lower levels of TUNEL-pos. cells (a marker for programmed cell death), and significantly less evidence for subsequent regeneration. CHOP therefore has a role in the induction of cell death under conditions assocd. with malfunction of the ER and may also have a role in cellular regeneration under such circumstances.

      p21WAF1 and tumourigenesis: 20 years after
      Warfel, Noel A.; El-Deiry, Wafik S.
      Current Opinion in Oncology (2013), 25 (1), 52-58CODEN: CUOOE8; ISSN:1040-8746. (Lippincott Williams & Wilkins)
      Purpose of review: This review provides an overview of the structure, regulation and physiol. functions of p21, the product of the cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor 1A (CDKN1A) gene, with a focus on its dual role in promoting and repressing biol. processes that are hallmarks of tumorigenesis. Recent findings: Recent work has provided a better understanding of the mol. mechanisms of how oncogenic signalling pathways influence p21 expression. In response to cellular stimuli, p21 expression is tightly regulated at transcriptional and post-translational levels through mechanisms involving RNA stabilization, phosphorylation and ubiquitination. As a result, growing evidence reveals that several important tumor suppressor and oncogenic signalling pathways alter p21 expression to elicit their effects on cell cycle progression and survival. Thus, p21 expression can both promote and inhibit tumorigenic processes, depending on the cellular context. Summary: Since its discovery, it has become increasingly clear that p21 can function as both a classical tumor suppressor and an oncogene. In order to effectively utilize p21 as a therapeutic target, it will be necessary to design therapeutic strategies that preferentially block the ability of p21 to promote senescence, stem cell renewal and cyclin/CDK activation, while leaving its tumor suppressive functions intact.

      Anticancer Activity of CX-3543: A Direct Inhibitor of rRNA Biogenesis
      Drygin, Denis; Siddiqui-Jain, Adam; O'Brien, Sean; Schwaebe, Michael; Lin, Amy; Bliesath, Josh; Ho, Caroline B.; Proffitt, Chris; Trent, Katy; Whitten, Jeffrey P.; Lim, John K. C.; Von Hoff, Daniel; Anderes, Kenna; Rice, William G.
      Cancer Research (2009), 69 (19), 7653-7661CODEN: CNREA8; ISSN:0008-5472. (American Association for Cancer Research)
      Hallmark deregulated signaling in cancer cells drives excessive ribosome biogenesis within the nucleolus, which elicits unbridled cell growth and proliferation. The rate-limiting step of ribosome biogenesis is synthesis of rRNA (building blocks of ribosomes) by RNA Polymerase I (Pol I). Numerous kinase pathways and products of proto-oncogenes can up-regulate Pol I, whereas tumor suppressor proteins can inhibit rRNA synthesis. In tumorigenesis, activating mutations in certain cancer-assocd. kinases and loss-of-function mutations in tumor suppressors lead to deregulated signaling that stimulates Pol I transcription with resultant increases in ribosome biogenesis, protein synthesis, cell growth, and proliferation. Certain anticancer therapeutics, such as cisplatin and 5-fluorouracil, reportedly exert, at least partially, their activity through disruption of ribosome biogenesis, yet many prime targets for anticancer drugs within the ribosome synthetic machinery of the nucleolus remain largely unexploited. Herein, we describe CX-3543, a small mol. nucleolus-targeting agent that selectively disrupts nucleolin/rDNA G-quadruplex complexes in the nucleolus, thereby inhibiting Pol I transcription and inducing apoptosis in cancer cells. CX-3543 is the first G-quadruplex interactive agent to enter human clin. trials, and it is currently under evaluation against carcinoid/neuroendocrine tumors in a phase II clin. trial. [Cancer Res 2009;69(19):7653-61].

      Induction of senescence in cancer cells by the G-quadruplex stabilizer, BMVC4, is independent of its telomerase inhibitory activity
      Huang, Fong-Chun; Chang, Cheng-Chung; Wang, Jing-Min; Chang, Ta-Chau; Lin, Jing-Jer
      British Journal of Pharmacology (2012), 167 (2), 393-406CODEN: BJPCBM; ISSN:1476-5381. (Wiley-Blackwell)
      Telomerase is the enzyme responsible for extending G-strand telomeric DNA and represents a promising target for treatment of neoplasia. Inhibition of telomerase can be achieved by stabilization of G-quadruplex DNA structures. Here, we characterize the cellular effects of a novel G-quadruplex stabilizing compd., 3,6-bis(4-methyl-2-vinylpyrazinium iodine) carbazole (BMVC4). The cellular effects of BMVC4 were characterized in both telomerase-pos. and alternative lengthening of telomeres (ALT) cancer cells. The mol. mechanism of how BMVC4 induced senescence is also addressed. BMVC4-treated cancer cells showed typical senescence phenotypes. BMVC4 induced senescence in both ALT and telomerase-overexpressing cells, suggesting that telomere shortening through telomerase inhibition might not be the cause for senescence. A large fraction of DNA damage foci was not localized to telomeres in BMVC4-treated cells and BMVC4 suppressed c-myc expression through stabilizing the G-quadruplex structure located at its promoter. These results indicated that the cellular targets of BMVC4 were not limited to telomeres. Further analyses showed that BMVC4 induced DNA breaks and activation of ataxia telangiectasia-mutated mediated DNA damage response pathway. BMVC4, a G-quadruplex stabilizer, induced senescence by activation of pathways of response to DNA damage that was independent of its telomerase inhibitory activity. Thus, BMVC4 has the potential to be developed as a chemotherapeutic agent against both telomerase pos. and ALT cancer cells.

      Overview of the CCP4 suite and current developments
      Winn, Martyn D.; Ballard, Charles C.; Cowtan, Kevin D.; Dodson, Eleanor J.; Emsley, Paul; Evans, Phil R.; Keegan, Ronan M.; Krissinel, Eugene B.; Leslie, Andrew G. W.; McCoy, Airlie; McNicholas, Stuart J.; Murshudov, Garib N.; Pannu, Navraj S.; Potterton, Elizabeth A.; Powell, Harold R.; Read, Randy J.; Vagin, Alexei; Wilson, Keith S.
      Acta Crystallographica, Section D: Biological Crystallography (2011), 67 (4), 235-242CODEN: ABCRE6; ISSN:0907-4449. (International Union of Crystallography)
      A review. The CCP4 (Collaborative Computational Project, No. 4) software suite is a collection of programs and assocd. data and software libraries which can be used for macromol. structure detn. by X-ray crystallog. The suite is designed to be flexible, allowing users a no. of methods of achieving their aims. The programs are from a wide variety of sources but are connected by a common infrastructure provided by std. file formats, data objects and graphical interfaces. Structure soln. by macromol. crystallog. is becoming increasingly automated and the CCP4 suite includes several automation pipelines. After giving a brief description of the evolution of CCP4 over the last 30 years, an overview of the current suite is given. While detailed descriptions are given in the accompanying articles, here it is shown how the individual programs contribute to a complete software package.

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      49
      Phaser crystallographic software
      McCoy, Airlie J.; Grosse-Kunstleve, Ralf W.; Adams, Paul D.; Winn, Martyn D.; Storoni, Laurent C.; Read, Randy J.
      Journal of Applied Crystallography (2007), 40 (4), 658-674CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (International Union of Crystallography)
      Phaser is a program for phasing macromol. crystal structures by both mol. replacement and exptl. phasing methods. The novel phasing algorithms implemented in Phaser have been developed using max. likelihood and multivariate statistics. For mol. replacement, the new algorithms have proved to be significantly better than traditional methods in discriminating correct solns. from noise, and for single-wavelength anomalous dispersion exptl. phasing, the new algorithms, which account for correlations between F+ and F-, give better phases (lower mean phase error with respect to the phases given by the refined structure) than those that use mean F and anomalous differences ΔF. One of the design concepts of Phaser was that it be capable of a high degree of automation. To this end, Phaser (written in C++) can be called directly from Python, although it can also be called using traditional CCP4 keyword-style input. Phaser is a platform for future development of improved phasing methods and their release, including source code, to the crystallog. community.

        (a) Davies, J. T. G-quartets 40 years later: from 5′-GMP to molecular biology and supramolecular chemistry Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2004, 43, 668– 698
